organization.fullName: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

identificationModule.briefTitle: Effectiveness of a Multi-Level Smoking Cessation Program for High-Risk Women in Rural Communities
identificationModule.officialTitle: Break Free: Effectiveness of a Multi-Level Smoking Cessation Program Adapted for High-Risk Women in Rural Communities

responsibleParty.investigatorAffiliation: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

leadSponsor.name: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This phase IV trial examines the effectiveness of a multi-level smoking cessation program for high-risk women in rural communities. Cigarette smoking is a major risk factor for cervical cancer in women. Rural primary care practices and providers often lack the electronic health record support to pre-identify smokers for services, as well as lack the necessary counseling training and access to comprehensive cessation programs. Implementing evidence-based smoking cessation programs in rural Appalachia may decrease the rates of cigarette smoking and as a result decrease the rates of cervical cancer.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
PRIMARY OBJECTIVES:

I. Determine the effectiveness of a core component of an integrated cervical cancer prevention program designed to help female smokers quit by standardizing clinical practice supports and protocols. (Service outcomes) II. Determine satisfaction with the multilevel intervention. (Client outcomes) III. Test the sustainability of the multilevel intervention via training of providers and staff on counseling and billing for evidence-based smoking cessation services. (Implementation outcomes)

OUTLINE:

IMPLEMENTATION OF TOBACCO-USER IDENTIFICATION SYSTEM: Clinics and systems develop and implement minimally required electronic tracking and reporting systems for identification of smokers during months 1-12.

GROUP RANDOMIZED TRIAL: Providers and participants are randomized to 1 of 2 arms.

ARM I (EARLY ARM): Providers undergo training over 60 minutes to explain the Break Free program and basics of quitting smoking during months 13-24. Female smokers interested in quitting in the next 6 months will be referred to an in-person counseling session at the clinic. Participants then receive 4 phone counseling over 15-20 minutes with a trained tobacco treatment specialist.

ARM II (DELAYED ARM): Female smokers receive usual care during months 13-24. Providers undergo training over 60 minutes to explain the Break Free program and basics of quitting smoking during months 25-36. Female smokers interested in quitting in the next 6 months will be referred to an in-person counseling session at the clinic. Participants then receive 4 phone counseling over 15-20 minutes with a trained tobacco treatment specialist.

armGroups.label: Arm I (early arm)
armGroups.description: Providers undergo training over 60 minutes to explain the Break Free program and basics of quitting smoking during months 13-24. Female smokers interested in quitting in the next 6 months will be referred to an in-person counseling session at the clinic. Participants then receive 4 phone counseling over 15-20 minutes with a trained tobacco treatment specialist.

armGroups.label: Arm II (delayed arm)
armGroups.description: Female smokers receive usual care during months 13-24. Providers undergo training over 60 minutes to explain the Break Free program and basics of quitting smoking during months 25-36. Female smokers interested in quitting in the next 6 months will be referred to an in-person counseling session at the clinic. Participants then receive 4 phone counseling over 15-20 minutes with a trained tobacco treatment specialist.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Acceptability of intervention - delivery of AAC
primaryOutcomes.description: This provider-level outcome includes self-reported changes in the delivery of the Ask, Advise, and Connect (AAC).
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Up to 6 months

primaryOutcomes.measure: Acceptability of intervention - referral rate
primaryOutcomes.description: This provider-level outcome includes the rate of referrals to the in-clinic smoking cessation counselor.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Up to 6 months

primaryOutcomes.measure: Fidelity to the intervention: counseling calls
primaryOutcomes.description: Measured by asking 10% of randomly selected women questions about content of the phone counseling.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Day after phone counseling during the span of the intervention (one year)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Fidelity to the intervention: provider visits
primaryOutcomes.description: Measured by self-administered, anonymous, post-provider visit surveys every other month by patients who were in the clinic for a visit during a one-week period. Patients will be asking whether the provider asked about tobacco use, if a smoker, advised the patient to quit, discussed cessation, and connected the smoker to counseling.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At time of in person visit for a one week span, every other month during the span of the intervention (one year)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Sustainability of the intervention: clinic continuation of Break Free
primaryOutcomes.description: Measured by self-reported continuation of cessation counseling by clinic staff
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During the span of the final phase of study (2 years)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Sustainability of the intervention: counseling sessions
primaryOutcomes.description: Measured by the number of counseling sessions billed for overall
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During the span of the final phase of study (2 years)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Sustainability of the intervention: counseling sessions per smoker
primaryOutcomes.description: Measured by the number of counseling sessions billed for each individual smoker who has at least one session
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During the span of the final phase of study (2 years)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Sustainability of the intervention: EHR documentation
primaryOutcomes.description: Measured by electronic health record documentation of tobacco use
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: During the span of the final phase of study (2 years)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Cost-effectiveness of intervention
primaryOutcomes.description: Will be assessed using standard costs by considering costs of each component including pharmacotherapy, clinic counselor time and training, smoking cessation counselor time and training, telephone and material costs, and other administrative costs.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Up to 6 months

primaryOutcomes.measure: Effectiveness of intervention at increasing brief cessation counseling: Change over time
primaryOutcomes.description: Will be assessed using patient post-visit surveys and see if they increase over time.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: 3 months, 6 months, 12 months

primaryOutcomes.measure: Point prevalence
primaryOutcomes.description: Measured using self-report of any tobacco use. Abstainers will be classified as those participants who self-report no use of tobacco during the past week.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Up to 7 days

primaryOutcomes.measure: Floating abstinence
primaryOutcomes.description: Defined as not smoking during any consecutive 7-day period since the last assessment. Self-reported by patients.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Up to 7 days

primaryOutcomes.measure: Prolonged abstinence
primaryOutcomes.description: Defined as no smoking after a two-week grace period from the quit date. Self-reported by patients.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At each follow-up visit over the span of the intervention (1 year)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Provider satisfaction
primaryOutcomes.description: Measured via provider surveys
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Mid-points of each provider arm during the intervention year (1 year)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Staff satisfaction
primaryOutcomes.description: Measured via staff surveys
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Mid-points of each provider arm during the intervention year (1 year)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Smoker satisfaction with Break Free counseling
primaryOutcomes.description: Measured via patient surveys
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At the end of each Break Free counseling sessions during the intervention year (year 1)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Smoker satisfaction during Break Free counseling
primaryOutcomes.description: Measured via patient surveys
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At the end of each Break Free counseling sessions during the intervention year (year 1)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Smoker satisfaction after Break Free program
primaryOutcomes.description: Measured via patient surveys
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At 6 months after completion of Break Free counseling

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in provider knowledge
primaryOutcomes.description: Using the Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) model, effectiveness of intervention on improved provider knowledge will be assessed.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, post-training (same day), 1 year

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in provider attitudes
primaryOutcomes.description: Using the Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) model, effectiveness of intervention on improved provider attitudes will be assessed.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, post-training (1 day), 1 year

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in provider's normative beliefs
primaryOutcomes.description: Using the Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) model, effectiveness of intervention on provider's normative beliefs will be assessed.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, post-training (1 day), 1 year

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in provider's perceived behavioral control
primaryOutcomes.description: Using the Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) model, effectiveness of intervention on provider's perceived behavioral control will be assessed.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, post-training (1 day), 1 year

primaryOutcomes.measure: Effectiveness of intervention of Improved provider knowledge and attitude
primaryOutcomes.description: Using the Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) model, attitudes, normative beliefs, and perceived behavioral control will be assessed.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, post-training (1 day), 1 year

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* HEALTH SYSTEM/CLINIC
* Based in one of the Appalachian regions included in this program project
* Provides care to female smokers
* PROVIDER
* Practicing in one of the participating health systems
* Involved in patient care
* PATIENT
* Females
* Age 18 to 64
* Smokers who consume at least 5 cigarettes per day (less than the minimum in most cessation studies, yet still enough to show signs of nicotine dependence)
* Ready to quit smoking in the next 6 months
* English-speaking
* Able to participate in counseling
* Willing to try smoking cessation pharmacotherapy
* Not pregnant

overallOfficials.name: Amy Ferketich, PhD
overallOfficials.affiliation: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

locations.facility: Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center

references.citation: Patterson JG, Borger TN, Burris JL, Conaway M, Klesges R, Ashcraft A, Hauser L, Clark C, Wright L, Cooper S, Smith MC, Dignan M, Kennedy-Rea S, Paskett ED, Anderson R, Ferketich AK. A cluster randomized controlled trial for a multi-level, clinic-based smoking cessation program with women in Appalachian communities: study protocol for the "Break Free" program. Addict Sci Clin Pract. 2022 Feb 14;17(1):11. doi: 10.1186/s13722-022-00295-5. Erratum In: Addict Sci Clin Pract. 2022 Apr 1;17(1):21. doi: 10.1186/s13722-022-00304-7.
